title: Gut microbiota-derived short-chain fatty acids promote follicular maturation via gWAT-ovary axis in mammals - Microbiome
description: Background Previous studies have demonstrated that gut microbiota regulates reproductive performance in mammals. Our prior research identified the gut microbiota-ovary axis as an important contributor to the superior follicular development observed in Chinese indigenous Meishan sows, yet the underlying mechanisms remain unclear. This study aims to elucidate the mechanism through which gut microbiota regulates follicular development. Results Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) from Meishan sows promoted follicular maturation in recipient Landrace × Yorkshire sows, evidenced by increased numbers of antral follicles, secondary follicles, and corpora lutea, accompanied by decreased atretic follicles. Additionally, FMT altered reproductive hormone profiles, significantly elevating estradiol secretion during the estrous cycle prior to sampling. Multi-omics analyses identified four key bacterial species of Fibrobacter intestinalis, Lactobacillus mucosae, Bifidobacterium thermophilum, and Ruminococcin flavefaciens, along with short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs), that are closely associated with follicular maturation. These microbial species and their shared metabolites SCFAs promoted follicular maturation and ovulation rate by inhibiting apoptosis of ovarian granulosa cells, thus reducing follicular atresia. Mechanistically, SCFAs activated G-protein-coupled receptor 43 (GPR43), which is highly expressed in peri-ovarian gonadal white adipose tissue (gWAT). This SCFAs-mediated activation of GPR43 stimulated leptin secretion from gWAT in a concentration-dependent manner, consequently suppressing granulosa cell apoptosis and promoting follicular maturation. Furthermore, in a large-scale validation trial, dietary SCFAs supplementation increased litter size by approximately 5.91%. Conclusion Collectively, gut microbiota-derived SCFAs promote follicular maturation and increase litter size in sows by stimulating leptin secretion from peri-ovarian gWAT, thus providing novel insights into enhancing reproductive outcomes in mammals. Abstract

Background

Previous studies have demonstrated that gut microbiota regulates reproductive performance in mammals. Our prior research identified the gut microbiota-ovary axis as an important contributor to the superior follicular development observed in Chinese indigenous Meishan sows, yet the underlying mechanisms remain unclear. This study aims to elucidate the mechanism through which gut microbiota regulates follicular development.

Results

Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) from Meishan sows promoted follicular maturation in recipient Landrace × Yorkshire sows, evidenced by increased numbers of antral follicles, secondary follicles, and corpora lutea, accompanied by decreased atretic follicles. Additionally, FMT altered reproductive hormone profiles, significantly elevating estradiol secretion during the estrous cycle prior to sampling. Multi-omics analyses identified four key bacterial species of Fibrobacter intestinalis, Lactobacillus mucosae, Bifidobacterium thermophilum, and Ruminococcin flavefaciens, along with short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs), that are closely associated with follicular maturation. These microbial species and their shared metabolites SCFAs promoted follicular maturation and ovulation rate by inhibiting apoptosis of ovarian granulosa cells, thus reducing follicular atresia. Mechanistically, SCFAs activated G-protein-coupled receptor 43 (GPR43), which is highly expressed in peri-ovarian gonadal white adipose tissue (gWAT). This SCFAs-mediated activation of GPR43 stimulated leptin secretion from gWAT in a concentration-dependent manner, consequently suppressing granulosa cell apoptosis and promoting follicular maturation. Furthermore, in a large-scale validation trial, dietary SCFAs supplementation increased litter size by approximately 5.91%.

Conclusion

Collectively, gut microbiota-derived SCFAs promote follicular maturation and increase litter size in sows by stimulating leptin secretion from peri-ovarian gWAT, thus providing novel insights into enhancing reproductive outcomes in mammals.

Introduction

The global demand for animal-based food products is anticipated to increase by 70% from 2015 to 2050 [1]. In particular, the global pork consumption is projected to reach 1.29 million tons over the next 10 years and to account for over a third of the total meat demands for human consumption [2, 3]. Pork production is a highly industrialized and environmentally concerned farming industry, which’s efficiency mainly depends on sows' reproductive performance [4, 5]. Improving sows’ reproductive performance could lower the demands for land, labor, and feedstuffs while producing the same amount of pork in the pig farming industry. However, reproduction traits of sows are quantitative traits with low heritability, especially litter size, which hindered the progress of traditional genetic breeding [6, 7]. Ovulation rate, the number of oocytes ovulated from matured follicles in the ovary per estrus cycle, constitutes a major limitation to increasing the litter size and productivity of sows [6, 8]. Besides traditional genetic factors, the gut microbiota, often referred to as the host’s second genome, has been shown to regulate reproductive performance [9,10,11,12,13,14,15,16,17].

China has rich genetic resources of indigenous sows, such as the Meishan sows which produce 11.3 mature follicles and ovulate 10.1 more oocytes than hybrid sows at first parity, offering a unique opportunity to explore the underlying mechanisms linking gut microbiota and sows' reproductive performance [18,19,20,21]. However, the genetic resources of the high reproductive trait of Meishan sows have mainly been used to genetically improve the reproductive capacity of commercial sows both in China and internationally [22], while there has been a lack of exploration and utilization of the physiological mechanisms behind their high ovulation rate trait. The results of an earlier comparative experiment between Meishan sows and white sows speculated that the high ovulation rate of Meishan sows may be related to the higher aromatase activity and estradiol synthesis rate of their granulosa cells, the higher follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)/luteinizing hormone (LH) ratio in plasma, and the higher expression levels of FSH receptors and estrogen receptors on granulosa cells, but further mechanistic analysis is lacking [20, 23].

As the host’s “second genome” and “endocrine organ”, gut microbiota has been widely proven to be involved in regulating the reproductive performance of female animals [15, 24, 25]. For sows, gut microbiota has been reported to affect sows’ litter size, but the underlying mechanisms remain obscure [26,27,28,29,30,31]. Here, to determine the causal relationship between gut microbiota and follicular development, we transplanted fecal microbiota of Meishan sows to the co-housed Landrace × Yorkshire (L × Y) sows. Then, we employed muti-omics (including 16S rRNA gene sequencing, metabolomics, and proteomics) to classify the core microbes that dominate the follicular development. The related metabolic pathways regulated by the core microbes were also identified. These findings will provide new insights into the physiological mechanism of the formation of follicular development advantages in Meishan sows, and at the same time provide new data and practical guidance for improving the litter size of commercial sows. It has important academic value and potential application value.

Results

FMT from Meishan sows promotes follicular maturation in recipient L × Y sows

To determine the causality between gut microbiota and ovarian follicular development, we transplanted fecal microbiota of Meishan sows to commercial L × Y sows (Fig. 1A). FMT shifted the gut microbiota of recipient L × Y sows and made them similar to those of the donor Meishan sows (Fig. 1B–E, Fig. S1A–G). FMT had no effect on the body weight (Fig. S2A), backfat thickness (Fig. S2B), and ovary weight (Fig. S2C). Strikingly, FMT significantly increased the counts of visible large follicles with diameter ≥ 5 mm, antral follicles, secondary follicles, and corpus luteum, but decreased the count of atretic follicles, respectively (Fig. 1F, G).

FMT from Meishan sows shifts the levels of reproductive hormones in recipient L × Y sows

Considering that reproductive hormones drive follicular development [32, 33], we determined plasma concentrations of FSH, LH, estradiol, and progesterone every other day during the third estrous cycle after FMT. LFMT increased the plasma concentrations of FSH (day 3 and 5) (Fig. 2A) and LH (day 3 and days 13–19) (Fig. 2B) in the third estrous cycle of recipient L × Y sows. LFMT increased the plasma estradiol concentrations throughout the third estrous cycle (days 5-19) (Fig. 2C). LFMT decreased the plasma progesterone concentration on day 9 in the third estrous cycle of recipient L × Y sows. There no significant differences in the plasma concentrations of FSH, LH, estradiol, and progesterone among the others groups. Since these hormones act or are produced in follicles, we determined their concentrations in follicular fluid. LFMT increased the concentrations of LH (Fig. 2F) and estradiol (Fig. 2G) in follicular fluid, decreased the progesterone concentration in follicular fluid (Fig. 2H), and had no significant effect on the FSH concentration in follicular fluid (Fig. 2E). There no significant differences in the concentrations of FSH, LH, estradiol, and progesterone in follicular fluid among the others groups.

FMT from Meishan sows regulates granulosa cells apoptosis to affect the fate of developing ovarian follicles

To figure out how the shifted gut microbiota affects the development and maturation of ovarian follicles, we comprehensively determined the structure and function of gut microbiota, and proteomics of ovary tissues (Fig. 3A). We found that Fibrobacteres, Fibrobacter intestinalis, Lactobacillus mucosae, Lactobacillus reuteri, Bifidobacterium thermophilum, Ruminococcin flavefaciens, and Ruminococcus bromii, as well as the carbohydrate metabolism capacity of gut microbiota, were enriched in LFMT recipient L × Y sows (Fig. 3B, C). Specially, the concentrations of SCFAs, including acetate, propionate, and butyrate, was increased in the feces of LFMT recipient L × Y sows (Fig. 3D), which supported the enhanced carbohydrate metabolism capacity of gut microbiota. With isobaric tag for relative and absolute quantitation (iTRAQ)-based quantitative proteomic analysis of ovary tissue (Fig. S3A, B), we showed that LFMT markedly induced 446 differentially expressed proteins (DEPs) from the identified total 6804 proteins (Fig. 3E), which are enriched in lysosome, apoptosis, and PI3K-AKT signaling pathways etc. (Fig. 3F). Given that apoptosis of granulosa cells in ovarian follicles causes the atresia of developing ovarian follicles [34], we checked the apoptosis levels of granulosa cells in ovarian follicles using DAB-TUNEL staining and found that LFMT suppressed the apoptosis of granulosa cells in secondary follicles and antral follicles (Fig. 3G). In addition, there are significant correlations between SCFAs/marker bacteria and both granulosa cells apoptosis and follicular development (Fig. 3H). These results suggested that gut microbiota takes part in the regulation of ovarian follicular development by regulating the apoptosis of ovarian granulosa cells.

FMT from Meishan sows shifted the metabolomic profiling of both plasma and liver tissue in recipient L × Y sows

To determine how the shifted gut microbiota affects the development and maturation of distal ovarian follicles, we comprehensively determined the metabolomics of plasma and liver tissues (Fig. 4A). We found that LFMT markedly shifted the metabolomic profiling of both plasma (Fig. 4B) and liver tissue (Fig. 4C), respectively. The LFMT-altered metabolites in plasma were enriched in fatty acids-related KEGG pathways of fatty acid metabolism, alpha-linolenic acid metabolism, and fatty acid elongation, etc. (Fig. 4F). And for liver tissues, the LFMT-altered metabolites were also enriched in fatty acids-related KEGG pathways of linoleic acid metabolism, alpha-linolenic acid metabolism, and biosynthesis of unsaturated fatty acids, etc. (Fig. 4G). Most of the LFMT-altered metabolites belong to lipids and lipid-like molecules in both plasma and liver tissue (Fig. 4H). The concentration of SCFAs, including acetate, propionate, and butyrate were also increased in the plasma of LFMT recipient L × Y sows (Fig. 4I).

The key bacteria and SCFAs suppress granulosa cells apoptosis in association with leptin secreted from gWAT

SCFAs and SCFAs-producing bacteria have been associated significantly with female's reproductive performance [25]. Given that oxidative stress is one of the main inducers of granulosa cells apoptosis, which results in the increases of atretic follicles [35], we then asked whether key bacteria and SCFAs could suppress follicular atresia and promote follicle maturation using a mice mode of ovarian granulosa cells oxidative stress (Fig. 5A and Fig. S4A–C). The results showed that key bacteria and SCFAs supplementation markedly increased the plasma concentrations of SCFAs (Fig. 5B). Key bacteria and SCFAs suppressed the granulosa cells apoptosis in ovary follicle (Fig. 5C, D), increased the counts of secondary follicle and antral follicle but decreased the atretic follicle (Fig. 5E). Of interest, we found that key bacteria and SCFAs markedly increased the relative weight of gWAT (Fig. 5F). Given that gWAT directly connect with ovary tissue and belong to white adipose tissue which could secrete leptin to affect follicular development and ovulation [36], we therefore determined the leptin in the plasma and found that key bacteria and SCFAs both increased the plasma leptin concentration (Fig. 5G). Further in situ with immunofluorescence showed that key bacteria and SCFAs significantly enhanced leptin secretion (Fig. 5H, I). Notably, leptin-deficient female mice showed sterility and enhanced the cell apoptosis of ovary tissue, and leptin treatment could correct their sterility, thus restoring ovulation, pregnancy, and parturition [37, 38]. Given that the follicular mature related key bacterial strains of Fibrobacter intestinalis, Lactobacillus mucosae, Bifidobacterium thermophilum, and Ruminococcin flavefaciens are all able to produce SCFAs [39,40,41,42], we supposed that SCFAs may suppress the oxidative stress-induced granulosa cells apoptosis by promoting leptin secreting from gWAT, which is supported by the significant correlation between SCFAs, gWAT, and leptin with the indices related to follicular development (Fig. 5J). The results indicated that gut microbiota derived SCFAs may suppress the oxidative stress-induced granulosa cells apoptosis via promoting leptin secreting of gWAT.

Leptin from gWAT mediated SCFAs' suppression on granulosa cells apoptosis

Early studies showed that knockout of leptin gene leads to sterility, never ovulation, and no occurrence of estrus cycles in female mice [38, 43]. Therefore, to determine the role of leptin in suppressing the effect of SCFAs on ovarian granulosa cells apoptosis and follicular atresia, we conducted knockdown, but not knockout of Lep gene using RNAi in vivo (Fig. 6A and Fig. S5A–D). In vivo knockdown of Lep with RNAi substantially decreased the expression level of Lep in gWAT, mWAT, and sWAT, respectively (Fig. 6B, C). SCFAs suppressed the oxidative stress-induced granulosa cell apoptosis (Fig. 6F and H), increased secondary follicle count and antral follicle count, but decreased atresia follicle count, which were suppressed by the knockdown of the gene Lep in gut microbiota-deleted mice (Fig. 6 F and G). Compared well with Fig. 5F, SCFAs supplementation also increased the gWAT weight, which was not affected by the knockdown of the gene Lep (Fig. 6D). As expected, the promoting effect of SCFAs on leptin secretion was suppressed by the knockdown of the Lep gene (Fig. 6J–K). We then explored the reason that SCFAs solely promoted the differentiation of the gWAT, but not other white adipose tissue. Given that SCFAs could stimulate adipogenesis via GPR43 and the GPR43 gene expression levels differ markedly in different white adipose tissue [44, 45], we determined GPR43 gene expression levels in mWAT, gWAT, and sWAT from mice and sows, respectively, and found that gWAT expressed higher levels of Gpr43 mRNA than mWAT and sWAT in mice (Fig. 6E). This may be the underlying reason for gut microbiota-derived SCFAs affecting host body fat distribution [46]. Besides, SCFAs supplementation also increased the expression of Gpr43, which was also not affected by the knockdown of the gene Lep (Fig. 6I). These results suggested SCFAs could enhance leptin secretion from the gWAT to suppress the oxidative stress-induced granulosa cell apoptosis and follicular atresia in mice.

GPR43-leptin axis mediated SCFAs suppressing oxidative stress-induced ovarian granulosa cell apoptosis

To understand the role of SCFAs sensor GPR43 in promoting follicular development, we generated Gpr43 gene knockout mice and treated them with SCFAs (Fig. 7A and Fig. S6A–E). SCFAs supplementation promoted follicular development and suppressed oxidative stress-induced ovarian granulosa cell apoptosis and follicular atresia in wild-type mice, whereas no such effect was observed in Gpr43−/− mice (Fig. 7B, C). Meanwhile, SCFAs supplementation markedly increased gWAT weight but had no statistical significance on the weight of mWAT and sWAT in wild-type mice, whereas no increased gWAT weight was observed in Gpr43−/− mice (Fig. 7D and Fig. S6F, G). The mRNA expression level of Gpr43 gene in wild-type mice was increased by SCFAs supplementation, but no expression was detected in Gpr43−/− mice ((Fig. 7E). Besides, the adipocyte size of gWAT (Fig. 7F, G), leptin secretion in gWAT (Fig. 7F) and leptin concentration in plasma (Fig. 7H) were increased after SCFAs supplementation in wild-type mice but not in Gpr43−/− mice. Treating adipocytes of gWAT from wild-type or Gpr43−/− mice with different concentrations of SCFAs in vitro showed that SCFAs enhance leptin secretion in a concentration-dependent manner (Fig. 7I, J). Besides, treating adipocytes with the optimal level of SCFAs on enhancing leptin production of the adipocytes (acetate 0.2 mM, propionate 0.1 mM, and butyrate 0.2 mM, respectively) could promote differentiation (Fig. 7K, L) of adipocytes from wild-type mice but not in adipocytes from Gpr43−/− mice. The results above concluded that GPR43-leptin signaling mediates the suppression effect of SCFAs on oxidative stress-induced granulosa cell apoptosis.

SCFAs promote follicular maturation via leptin-PI3K-AKT mediated suppression on granulosa cell apoptosis

Leptin plays an indispensable role in attenuating the apoptosis of granulosa cells in vivo, but this role is not identical in other experiments in vitro [47,48,49,50]. Here, we found that leptin could suppress H2O2-induced apoptosis in porcine ovarian granulosa cells in vitro (Fig. 8A, B). Further RNA sequencing analysis showed that leptin induced different expressed genes (DEGs) were significantly enriched in PI3K-AKT signaling pathway (Fig. S7A–E and Fig. 8C, D). Leptin had been reported to exert anti-apoptotic effects on goose granulosa cells through the PI3K-AKT signaling pathway [49]. Given that PI3K-AKT signaling pathway had also been enriched by the LFMT-induced DEPs in ovarian tissue (Fig. 3F), we determined the mRNA levels of the main genes of PI3K-AKT signaling pathway. Leptin increased the mRNA levels of LEPR, PI3K, JAK2, AKT1, AKT2, BCL2, and Caspase-3 (Fig. 8E). With the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, we found that PI3K was necessary for leptin's suppression effect on oxidative stress-induced granulosa cell apoptosis in vitro (Fig. 8F, G) and in vivo (Fig. 8H–K).

Dietary SCFAs supplementation promoted follicular maturation and increased litter size in sows

We then asked whether these key bacterial strains and their metabolites SCFAs could promote sow's follicular development by dietary SCFAs supplementation (Fig. 9A, B). SCFAs supplementation promoted the follicular maturation by increasing secondary follicle, antral follicle, corpus luteum, and litter size, but decreased atresia follicle (Fig. 9C–E). SCFAs supplementation did not affect body weight (Fig. S8A), backfat thickness (Fig. S8B), and ovary weight (Fig. S8C) in sows. SCFAs supplementation increased GPR43 gene expression in gWAT, but not in mWAT and sWAT (Fig.S8D). Compared well with in vitro results, SCFAs increased mRNA levels of LEPR, PI3K, JAK2, Akt1, Akt2, and Caspase-3 in follicular granulosa cell (Fig. 9F). SCFAs supplementation had no significant effect on the adipocytes size of gWAT (Fig. 9G, H and Fig. S8E, F), promoted leptin secretion from gWAT (Fig. 9 G and I), not from mWAT and sWAT (Fig. S8E and Fig. S8G). As a result, SCFAs supplementation increased leptin concentration in follicular fluid (Fig. 9J).

Discussion

Using purebred Meishan sows, a Chinese indigenous high-ovulation rate and high-litter size pig breed, we found that gut microbiota plays a vital role in the development, maturation, and eventually ovulation of ovarian follicles by FMT. FMT from Meishan sows promoted the follicular maturation of the recipient L × Y sows. Given that follicular development is driven by reproductive hormones [32, 33], we monitored the major reproductive hormones in plasma and follicular fluid and found that FMT modulated the plasma FSH, LH, and estradiol concentrations in the third estrous cycle of recipient L × Y sows, but had no significant effect on progesterone concentrations. Since these hormones act or are produced in the follicles, we further measured their concentrations in follicular fluid and found that FMT increased the concentrations of LH and estradiol in the follicular fluid; decreased the concentration of progesterone in the follicular fluid; and had no significant effect on the concentration of FSH in the follicular fluid. An earlier study found that an increase in the FSH/LH ratio may be associated with an increased ovulation rate in Meishan sows [23]. Miller et al. (1998) found that the concentration of estradiol in the follicular fluid of Meishan sows was higher than that of hybrid white pigs [20]. These reports are consistent with the increased concentration of estradiol in the follicular fluid of LFMT recipient sows. In contrast to estradiol, FMT reduced the concentration of progesterone in follicular fluid, which may be due to the fact that the peak of progesterone concentration in the estrous cycle usually occurs earlier in Meishan sows than in L × Y sows [51]. Since estradiol in follicular fluid is a marker of preovulatory oocyte quality [52], the continued significant increase in estradiol concentration throughout the third estrous cycle attracted our attention. The steroid hormone estradiol is mainly secreted by granulosa cells of ovarian follicles [53], indicating that FMT enhanced the synthesis and secretion of steroid estrogens in the ovaries of recipient L × Y sows [53, 54]. Through comparable trials and multi-omics analysis, we identified follicular maturation and ovulation-related bacterial strains (such as Fibrobacter intestinalis, Lactobacillus mucosae, Bifidobacterium thermophilum, and Ruminococcin flavefaciens) that share common gut microbial metabolites known as SCFAs [39,40,41,42]. These bacterial strains and SCFAs have also been found to be enriched in high-litter size sows of cross-bred commercial white sows and purebred Meishan sows [26, 31].

Pig farming is a highly intensified industry in which pigs suffer oxidative stress because of the disregard of their natural living habits, stalls, and high-intensity breeding activities etc. in China [55, 56]. Considering that oxidative stress as an initiator of follicular selective atresia and therefore impairs sow's reproductive performance [19], with 3-nitropropionic acid (3-NP) induced oxidative stress model of ovarian granulosa cells in vivo, we demonstrated that the bacterial strains or their metabolites SCFAs could obviously suppress the apoptosis of granulosa cells, facilitate follicular maturation, and decrease atretic follicles. As SCFAs concentrations in follicular fluid are too low to activate their receptors [57, 58], secondary signaling induced by SCFAs was considered. Extraordinarily, we found SCFAs promoted the adipocyte differentiation and the hormone leptin secretion in gWAT that expressed higher levels of GPR43 gene than mWAT and sWAT mice and sows. The white adipose tissues differential expression of GPR43 gene has also been reported in other studies [44, 45] and may account for the role of the gut microbiome and SCFAs in regulating body fat distribution [46, 59].

Nutrition impacts puberty, menstrual cycle, ovulation, fertilization, embryo implantation, and early fetal development [25]. Due to the high energy demands of reproduction, leptin as a crucial part of energy/nutritional status signaling, its sufficient levels are required for puberty onset, reproductive function, and fertility [60]. Besides, leptin has been reported to regulate the apoptosis of ovarian granulosa cells [61,62,63,64]. However, whether leptin exerts anti- or pro-apoptosis remains disputable [50, 62,63,64]. Here, with knockdown of the Lep gene in vivo, we demonstrated leptin mediates the suppressing effect of SCFAs on the apoptosis of granulosa cells. However, the pathway that SCFAs stimulate leptin production in adipocytes remains debatable [65, 66]. Xiong et al. reported that SCFAs stimulate leptin expression in both a mouse adipocyte cell line and mouse adipose tissue in primary culture via G-protein-coupled receptor 41 (GPR41) [66]. Inconsistently, Zaibi, Stocker et al. showed that GPR43, not GPR41, mediated leptin secretory responses of murine adipocytes to SCFAs [65]. Here, compared well with Zaibi, Stocker et al., we found that the expression of Gpr41 gene cannot be detected in gWAT and SCFAs elevated the expression level of Gpr43 in gWAT. Besides, we demonstrated that Gpr43 knockout suppressed the effect of SCFAs supplementation on promoting adipocyte differentiation of gWAT, simulating leptin production, and suppressing the apoptosis of granulosa cells. Further in vivo evidence suggested that SCFAs facilitate adipogenesis and suppress lipolysis via GPCR43 in a concentration dependent manner, which may explain the inconsistent reports about SCFAs' role in the adipogenesis and differentiation of adipocytes [44, 45, 67,68,69,70]. However, the further molecular mechanisms by which SCFAs stimulate leptin production, such as regulation of the leptin promoter, remain unexplored. The role of leptin on the apoptosis of granulosa cells has not reached a consensus conclusion [48, 49, 61, 71]. Here, we found that leptin (10 ng/mL) could suppress oxidative stress-induced granulosa cell apoptosis via PI3K-AKT signaling in porcine granulosa cells, which was further invalidated in vivo in a 3-NP induced oxidative stress of ovarian granulosa cells in mice. For determining the effect of dietary SCFAs supplementation on sows' follicular maturation and litter size, we conducted a large-scale sow trial in a commercial pig farm and found that SCFAs supplementation could promote follicular maturation and increase litter size by 0.73 per litter (5.91%) via facilitating leptin secretion from gWAT tissues to suppress granulosa cells apoptosis. The considerable return rate makes SCFAs supplementation a highly cost-effective nutritional intervention.

Conclusion

Taken together, gut microbiota derived SCFAs promoted adipocyte differentiation and leptin secretion of gWAT via GPR43 to suppress granulosa cell apoptosis and promote follicular maturation. Our findings uncover a new pathway that establishes a regulatory loop within the gut-ovary axis, significantly enriching our understanding of the molecular connections between ovarian follicular development and gut microbiota. The enhancement of host ovulation rates through gut microbiota-derived SCFAs presents an efficient nutritional strategy, contributing to sustainable pig production with reduced land, labor, and feed requirements.

Materials and methods

Animals and bacteria

Meishan sows and L × Y sows were housed in the National Engineering and Technology Research Center for Livestock and fed with diets according to NRC (2012). We got Ffar2 gene (GPR43) knockout mice (C57BL/6N-Ffar2em1cyagen) from Cyagen Biosciences Inc. (China) and ICR mice from Animal Experiment Center of Huazhong Agricultural University. All mice were kept in a specific pathogen-free facility in 12-h day/night cycles, unless otherwise specified.

The Ffar2 knockout mouse model (C57BL/6N-Ffar2em1cyagen) created using CRISPR/Cas-mediated genome engineering was provided by Cyagen Biosciences Inc. (China). Inter-cross heterozygous targeted mice to generate homozygous targeted mice. In detail, the pups will be genotyped by PCR followed by sequencing analysis (F1: 5′-ACCTGATCTTTCCCAGCTTCTATG-3′, R1: 5′-CATATCCAACAGGACCTTATCAGC-3′, and R2: 5′-GGTCAGATTAAGCAGGAGGATGTG-3′), pups with one band with 547 bp are Homozygous, pups with three bands with 547 bp, 594 bp, and 2291 bp are heterozygous, pups with two bands with 594 bp and 2291 bp are wild type (band 2291 bp cannot be detected usually but does not affect the genotype results).

These four fertility-associated strains include Fibrobacter intestinalis (DSM No.:104696; Medium 1668), Lactobacillus mucosae (DSM No.: 13346; Medium 11), Bifidobacterium thermophilum (DSM No.: 20210; Medium 58), and Ruminococcin flavefaciens (DSM No.: 25089; Medium 436) were isolated from the feces of sows directly using the corresponding selective medium to investigate the causality between the identified fertility-associated intestinal microbes and follicle development. These strains isolated were further identified by bacterial 16S rRNA gene sequencing.

16S rRNA gene sequencing for microbiota analysis

The extracted fecal microbial genomic DNA sample was amplificated with the GoLay-barcoded 515F/806R primers targeting the V4 region of the bacterial and archeal 16S rRNA gene. The generated DNA pool was then sequenced on the Illumina HiSeq system with the sequencing strategy PE300 and then the sequencing data were analyzed using the Quantitative Insights into Microbial Ecology software package with Benjamini–Hochberg FDR correction with q < 0.05 as the significance threshold.

Functional analysis of gut microbiota by PICRUSt2

To provide information about the functional composition of gut bacterial communities, we employed PICRUSt2 to predict the gene family abundances of bacterial communities based on the 16S rRNA gene data and a database of the latest version of reference genomes with Benjamini–Hochberg FDR correction with q < 0.05 as the significance threshold.

Quantitative enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay

Reproductive-related hormones leptin in plasma was quantified by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. We collected plasma samples using EDTA as an anticoagulant and follicular fluid samples, and then the samples were centrifuged for 15 min at 1500 × g and 4 °C. The supernatant was removed and assayed immediately. Alternatively, aliquot and store samples at – 20 °C or – 80 °C. Centrifuge the sample again after thawing before the assay. Avoid repeated freeze–thaw cycles. All samples were measured in 3 replicates following the recommended procedures in the instruction.

SCFAs quantification

Intestinal content samples were weighed into 1.5 mL tubes, crushed, and homogenized in 100 μL of distilled water. Subsequently, 40 mg of sodium chloride, 20 mg of citric acid, 40 μL of 1 M hydrochloric acid, and 200 μL of butanol were added. The tubes were vortexed for 2 min and centrifuged at 18,000 × g for 15 min. The supernatant was transferred to microtubes, and 1 μL was injected into the gas chromatograph. For plasma measurements, 20 mg of sodium chloride, 10 mg of citric acid, 20 μL of 1 M hydrochloric acid, and 100 μL of butanol were added to 100 μL of plasma samples. Tubes were vortexed and centrifuged as previously described and 1 μL was injected into the gas chromatograph. To quantify SCFAs, a calibration curve for the concentration range of 0.015–1 mg/mL was constructed. SCFAs measurements were performed following a recently published protocol [72].

H&E staining

H&E staining was performed as previously described with minor modifications. Briefly, ovaries or gWAT were preserved in 4% paraformaldehyde overnight at 4 °C (Sigma-Aldrich). The tissues were subsequently embedded in paraffin wax (Fisher Scientific) following immersion in a graded series of alcohols (70–100%). Embedded tissue was sliced (5 mm) using a rotary microtome. The slices were adhered to microscope slides and dried at 56 °C for 24 h. Next, slides were passed through a series of the clearing agent xylene and rehydrated in a graded series of ethanol (100%, 100%, 100%, 95%, 80%). After a brief wash in distilled water, the slides were incubated with hematoxylin solution. The slices were then washed with running tap water to remove excess hematoxylin. Then, the slices were differentiated in 1% acid alcohol for 30 s and washed with running tap water for 1 min. This step was followed by an incubation in the eosin counterstain, subsequent dehydration in a graded series of ethanol (80%, 95%, 95%, 95%, 100%, 100%, 100%), and immersion in xylene.

Follicle counting

Follicle counting was performed using H&E-stained ovary slices as previously described with minor modifications. Briefly, primordial follicles were characterized as having a compact oocyte surrounded by a single layer of flattened granulosa cells, while primary follicles were identified by the presence of an enlarged oocyte surrounded by a single layer of cuboidal granulosa cells. Secondary follicles were defined as having an enlarged oocyte surrounded by at least a partial or complete second layer of cuboidal granulosa cells but no more than four complete layers of cuboidal granulosa cells. Antral follicles were characterized by the presence of areas of follicular fluid (antrum) or a single large antral space. The follicles usually at the stage of late secondary or antral follicles had an aberrant oocyte and multiple layers of pycnotic granulosa cells were deemed atretic follicles.

Untargeted metabolomics profiling

For plasma and liver tissue sample, all samples were acquired by the liquid chromatography–mass spectrometry (LC–MS) system followed machine orders. Firstly, all chromatographic separations were performed using an ultra-performance liquid chromatography system (Waters, UK). For the MS/MS detection, all precursors were fragmented using 20–40 eV, and the scan time was 0.2 s. During the acquisition, the LE signal was acquired every 3 s to calibrate the mass accuracy. Furthermore, to evaluate the stability of the LC–MS during the whole acquisition, a quality control sample (Pool of all samples) was acquired after every 10 samples. Peak extraction is mainly achieved through the commercial software Progenesis QI (version 2.2) with Benjamini–Hochberg FDR correction with q < 0.05 as the significance threshold, including peak alignment, peak extraction, normalization, deconvolution, and compound identification. Based on QC sample information, local polynomial regression fitting signal correction (Quality control–based robust LOESS signal correction, QC-RSC) is performed on the real sample signal [73].

FMT experiment

The fecal suspension was prepared using the protocol previously described with minor optimization. Briefly, fresh feces samples were obtained from Meishan sows and were immediately homogenized in sterile and O2-free saline solution. Then fecal slurry was passed through the sterilized gauze and then a 0.224 mm stainless cell strainer to remove the particles. We used optical microscopy combined with methylene blue staining to count the live microbes in the fecal suspension. The Meishan sow's neighbor L × Y sows received sterile saline (20 mL), sterilized fecal microbiota suspension (20 mL), low concentration fecal microbiota suspensions (107 CFU/mL, 20 mL), and high concentration fecal microbiota suspensions (108 CFU/mL, 20 mL) every other day from the age of 90 days to the age of puberty onset (about 200 days of age). Ovary tissue, plasma sample, and intestine stool were collected at the terminal of the third estrus.

Quantitative proteomics

Quantitative proteomics iTRAQ were conducted to determine the protein profile of ovary. After protein extraction, protein digestion, peptide labeling, and peptide fractionation, LC–MS/MS analysis was performed. For bioinformatics pipeline for data analysis, an automated software called IQuant for quantitatively analyzing the labeled peptides with isobaric tags. It integrates Mascot Percolator, a well performing machine learning method for rescoring database search results, to provide reliable significance measures. We applied Benjamini–Hochberg FDR correction with q < 0.05 as the significance threshold. To assess the confidence of peptides, the PSMs were pre-filtered at a PSM-concentration FDR of 1%. Then based on the “simple principle” (The parsimony principle), identified peptide sequences are assembled into a set of confident proteins. To control the rate of false-positive at protein concentration, a protein FDR at 1%, which is based on Picked protein FDR strategy, will also be estimated after protein inference (Protein-concentration FDR ≤ 0.01). Proteins with 1.5-fold change and Q value less than 0.05 were determined as differentially expressed proteins in single replicate. Proteins with 1.5-fold change (mean value of all comparison groups) and P value (t test of all comparison groups) less than 0.05 were defined as differentially expressed proteins.

RNA extraction and cDNA synthesis

Total RNA was extracted using TRIzol Reagent (Thermo Fisher Scientific), and 2 mg total RNA was used for cDNA synthesis with reverse transcription master mix (Thermo Fisher Scientific) according to the manufacturers instructions. RNA concentrations and the 260/280 nm absorbance ratio were determined using NanoDrop 2000 (Thermo, USA).

Quantitative real-time PCR

qPCR was performed with the iTaq Universal SYBR Green Super Mix (Bio-Rad) on a CFX384 Real-Time PCR system (Bio-Rad) and changes in gene expression were calculated relative to Actb or 18S. All RT-qPCR primer pairs are listed in Supplementary Table 1.

Antibiotic treatment

A broad-spectrum antibiotic cocktail (1.0 g/L ampicillin and 0.5 g/L neomycin) was administered in the drinking water and changed once a week as described [74]. Successful depletion of gut microbiota after the antibiotic cocktail treatment was confirmed by gross cecal appearance and cecal microbiota quantification using qPCR analysis of total bacterial 16S rRNA gene copy number.

Oral administration of follicular maturation-associated key bacterial strains or SCFAs in mice

After antibiotics cocktail treatment for 5 days, mice received 0.2 mL sterile saline, 0.2 mL follicular maturation-associated key bacterial strains of Fibrobacter intestinalis (107 CFU/mL), Lactobacillus mucosae (107 CFU/mL), Bifidobacterium thermophilum (107 CFU/mL), and Ruminococcin flavefaciens (107 CFU/mL), respectively. The oral administration was conducted every other day from 18 to 22 days of age and samples were collected at the time of third estrus onset.

For SCFAs treatment, mice were treated with an antibiotic cocktail and then were free to SCFAs (41.5 mM acetate, 22.7 mM propionate, and 8.7 mM butyrate) supplemented drinking water that prepared and changed daily. We arrived at the concentration of SCFAs treatment based on the concentration of cecal SCFAs in the mice treated with a mixture of the four fertility-associated microbes. We tested the oral administration of concentration gradient of SCFAs including 0.5, 1, 2, 3, and 4-fold of the cecal concentration and found the onefold gained the best effect in promoting follicular development. Control mice received water (pH and sodium-matched) and changed daily.

Dietary SCFAs supplementation in sows

Around 2200 L × Y sows with a similar age (100 ± 13 days) were fed with basal diet (Ctrl group, n = 1000), or basal diet supplemented with 0.13% acetate, 0.11% propionate, and 0.09% butyrate (SCFAs group, n = 1200) until puberty. At the third estrus, sows (n = 6 for Ctrl group and n = 7 for SCFAs group, respectively) were randomly selected to sacrifice at 24 h after detection of the third estrus, and the other sows received artificial insemination. The litter sizes of sows were recorded. The basal diet (Table S1) was prepared according to the National Research Council [75].

Immunohistochemistry analysis

The paraffin-embedded sows ovary tissue slices were deparaffinized and hydrated through graded alcohols. After antigen retrieval, 3% BSA was added to the circle to evenly cover the tissue, and the tissues were sealed for 30 min at room temperature. The primary antibody prepared with PBS (pH7.4) in a certain proportion is added to the slices, and the slices are placed flat in a wet box and incubated overnight at 4 °C. And then the tissues are covered with secondary antibody (HRP labeled) from the corresponding species of primary antibody and incubated at room temperature for 50 min. DAB color developing solution newly prepared is added in the circle after the slices are slightly dried.

Immunofluorescence

After deparaffinize and rehydrate, slides were treated for antigen retrieval: immerse the slides in EDTA antigen retrieval buffer (pH 8.0) and maintain at a sub-boiling temperature for 8 min, standing for 8 min and then followed by another sub-boiling temperature for 7 min; wash three times with PBS (pH 7.4) in a Rocker device, 5 min each. Slides were then blocked with blocking buffer (3% bovine serum albumin in PBS) for 30 min at room temperature in a humid chamber. For leptin visualization, a polyclonal rabbit anti-mouse leptin-specific antibody (Affinity, DF8583) was diluted 1:200 in blocking buffer, applied to the slide, and incubated overnight at 4 °C. The secondary antibody (AlexaFluor 594 conjugated goat anti-rabbit IgG (H + L) Ab (Red)) was diluted 1:100 in blocking buffer with 10 mg/mL DAPI (Sigma), added to the sample, and incubated in the dark at 4 °C for 50 min. After incubation with the secondary antibody and DAPI, slides were washed three times in PBS, dried, and mounted with anti-fade mounting medium. Slides were stored at 4 °C in the dark until imaging.

Culture of porcine granulosa cells

Porcine granulosa cells were collected from healthy ovarian follicles (3–7 mm diameter) by puncturing and aspirating with a syringe. The granulosa cells were washed and centrifuged (1000 × g, 5 min), and then inoculated in a 6-cm dish at a density of 1 × 106 cells. Cells were cultured in a high glucose Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (DMEM), containing 15% FBS, 100 units/mL penicillin, and 100 mg/mL streptomycin at 37 °C in 5% CO2. When the confluence of the cells reached approximately 90% (about 6 days), the cells were transferred to a new plate for the next experiment.

RNA interference of leptin in vivo

The control small interfering RNA (siRNA) and the siRNA specifically designed to silence leptin expression in vivo were obtained from BBI (Shanghai, China). The sequences used to target leptin were as the following: GCAGGACAUUCUUCAACAGUUTT (sense,5′−3′); AACUGUUGAAGAAUGUCCUGCTT (antisense, 5′−3′). For in vivo RNA interference, siRNA was prepared in cationic liposome based Invivofectamine 3.0 Reagent (Cat#: IVF3001, Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA, USA). In brief, 50 μL siRNA at 2.4 mg/mL in DNase/RNase-free water was mixed with 50 μL complexation buffer, and then mixed with 100 μL Invivofectamine 3.0 Reagent. The diluted siRNA solution was vortexed immediately and incubated at 50 °C for 30 min. The transfection mixture was then diluted sixfold with 1 mL PBS, and then in vivo delivered into mice through tail vein injection at the final concentration of 1 mg/kg body weight. Mice were injected once every 5 days.

Ovarian oxidative stress in vivo model

The ovarian granulosa cells' oxidative stress in vivo model was established as reported. Briefly, gut microbiota-deleted female ICR mice were intraperitoneally injected with PBS or 3-nitropropionic acid (3-NP; Sigma-Aldrich, N5636) twice daily for 5 days at a dose of 50 mg/kg [76]. 3-NP was dissolved in PBS to a concentration of 10 mg/mL (pH 7.4) before the intraperitoneal injection.

Culture of primary adipocytes

Adipocytes were released from mouse gWAT by Collagenase Type I (Gibco 17018029) digestion. Cells were then washed four times with PBS buffer with 1% penicillin–streptomycin (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO, USA), and were then cultured in a humidified incubator at 37 °C with 5% CO2, using a high glucose DMEM (Hyclone, South Logan, UT, USA) supplemented with 1% penicillin–streptomycin (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO, USA) and 15% fetal bovine serum (Hyclone, South Logan, UT, USA) at a density of 1 × 106 cells after centrifugation (1000 × g, 5 min). Cells were incubated with a serial concentration of SCFAs, respectively.

Data availability

The 16S rDNA datasets (PRJNA659875) have been deposited in the Genome Sequence Archive linked to the project PRJNA659875. The iTRAQ proteomics datasets (IPX0011733002) have been deposited in the iProX linked to the project PXD063053.
